feed.title: Combined summary - Future of the bitcoin-dev mailing list

entry.title: Combined summary - Future of the bitcoin-dev mailing list
entry.summary:
Bitcoin developers are discussing alternatives to traditional mailing list infrastructure due to concerns about centralization, particularly with Google Groups. They value the decentralized nature of email for its archival capabilities and freedom from censorship. Nostr is a potential tool being considered for its decentralized approach but is recognized as needing further development before it can serve as a robust solution. In the meantime, other solutions like P2P networks for email systems and temporary measures such as Delving Bitcoin are being explored.
Nostrâ€™s development includes discussions on implementing relay system features to enable message subscription and filtering. However, there are recognized limitations and security concerns, prompting consideration of running personal mail servers. Self-hosted instances like Delvingbitcoin.org offer more sophisticated thread management and moderation than standard email, despite resource demands and privacy issues. An anti-spam fee via the lightning network is proposed to deter spam in mailing lists.
Bitcoin developers are evaluating communication platforms amid the Linux Foundation's decision to stop hosting mailing lists. The community is contemplating whether to find a new host for the bitcoin-dev mailing list or create a new platform. Simple Machines Forum (SMF) is recommended for its user-friendly moderation and search functionality. There is an emphasis on effective archiving systems, and Blockchain Commons has integrated GitHub discussions into their process as a familiar collaborative platform. The debate continues over adopting Nostr for communication, considering its complexity and the need for custom software solutions.
Matrix is proposed as an alternative communication platform, appreciated for its federated nature and encryption. The community previously transitioned from Sourceforge.net to the Linux Foundation and then to OSUOSL, highlighting a history of migrations in search of effective discussion hosting. Decentralized archiving through public-inbox instances and git repositories is suggested to maintain historical content.
Dan introduces Nostr for its advantages over traditional mailing systems, such as avoiding server blocking and reduced costs, but notes missing features like an email gateway. Groups.io and Google Groups are considered for migration, with Google Groups preferred for stability. The current mailman2 platform faces challenges with moderation and spam, leading to the exploration of self-hosting and web forums with integrated email interfaces. Community feedback is requested on these migration options to ensure continuity and coordination within the developer community.
For additional information on Matrix and Synapse home servers, resources are available at https://matrix.org/ and https://github.com/matrix-org/synapse.
